chapter.htmlHeader: How should I confirm if a person is overweight or obese?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Use clinical judgement to decide when to measure a person's height and weight.
    • Opportunities include during registration with a general practice, consultation for related conditions (such as type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease), and other routine health checks.
  • Approach the subject of weight carefully because people who are overweight or obese may be sensitive about discussing it, or feel that their presenting problem is being overlooked.
    • The Public Health England (PHE) guidance on Adult weight management: a guide to brief interventions includes a step-by-step guide to brief interventions with adults for healthcare professionals, which offers advice on consultations with overweight and obese people regarding weight loss. 
  • Calculate the person's body mass index (BMI) by dividing their weight in kilograms by the square of their height in metres. An online calculator is available at www.nhs.uk.
    • The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) defines different weight classes according to their BMI as:
      • Healthy weight — BMI of 18.5-24.9 kg/m2
      • Overweight — BMI of 25-29.9 kg/m2
      • Obesity l — BMI of 30-34.9 kg/m2
      • Obesity ll — BMI of 35-39.9 kg/m2
      • Obesity lll — BMI of 40 kg/m2 or more
    • Interpret BMI with caution in very muscular adults and in people with atrophy, as it is a less accurate measure of adiposity in these groups.
  • Consider using waist circumference, in addition to BMI, in people with a BMI of less than 35 kg/m2. 
    • The waist circumference provides an indication of total body fat and a risk of obesity-related health problems.
      • A waist circumference of 94 cm or more in men (90 cm or more for Asian men) and 80 cm or more in women indicates an increased risk of obesity-related health problems.
      • A waist circumference of 102 cm or more in men and 88 cm or more in women indicates a very high risk of obesity-related health problems.
  • Do not use bioimpedance as a substitute for BMI as a measure of general adiposity.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Obesity: identification, assessment and management [NICE, 2014] (which replaces section 1.2 in the NICE guideline on Obesity Prevention [NICE, 2006a]). For detailed information on the evidence NICE used to make these recommendations, see the full NICE guideline. These recommendations are generally in line with recommendations (and expert opinion) in several obesity guidelines, including the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of obesity guideline [SIGN, 2010] and the European Guidelines for Obesity Management in Adults [Yumuk, 2015]; the British National Formulary (BNF) [BNF 74, 2017]; and review articles on obesity, including the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice review article [BMJ, 2016].

Body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference

  • Although BMI is a useful indicator of overall body fat, experts warn that it should be interpreted with caution as it is not a direct measure of adiposity and so does not distinguish between mass due to body fat and mass due to muscular physique. It also does not take into account the distribution of fat [SIGN, 2010; NICE, 2014; BNF 74, 2017].
  • The amount of abdominal fat can be assessed by measuring waist circumference, which correlates with intra-abdominal fat content [Yumuk, 2015]. Waist circumference may provide an indication of total body fat and a risk of obesity-related health problems [BNF 74, 2017].
  • Further information on the use of BMI and waist circumference can be found in the NICE guideline on Body mass index and waist circumference thresholds for intervening to prevent ill health among black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups.

Bioimpedance

  • NICE advises that bioimpedance should not be used as a substitute for BMI as a measure of general adiposity [NICE, 2014].
  • Expert opinion in the European Guidelines for Obesity Management in Adults is that although assessment of body composition (for example using bioimpedance analysis) is not essential for the management of obesity in routine clinical practice, it may be a useful tool in measuring fat and fat-free mass before and during treatment [Yumuk, 2015]. 
  • Expert opinion in a BMJ Best Practice review article is that bioimpedance analysis (and other methods for determining body composition) are complicated, expensive, and not popular enough to be put into general use [BMJ, 2016].
